thread.title: Nike: More Pain On The Way?
thread.title_full: Nike: More Pain On The Way?

posts.title: Nike: More Pain On The Way?
posts.text:
Nike investors do not have to add more shares now. 
Below $48, the stock may drop to $40. 
Both technicals and fundamentals prove that $40 be an ideal entry point. Nike (NYSE: NKE ) has been a painful stock for the investors this year. Having lost more than 25 percent from its all-time high of $68.19, the stock still languishes near the 52-week low even as the broader market scales fresh highs. Although the decline seems tempting to add more shares at $50, I believe that investors would be better off postponing their purchases, and adding closer to $40. Click to enlarge Source: TechCrunch The primary reason for not recommending a purchase at the current level is because an investor should be willing to weather a 20-25 percent decline in his stock value. So, investors who bought near the top don't necessarily have to rush in to add now. Adding now would make strong business sense only if there is high conviction that the downtrend is over and the stock is primed for a rally . Technically, the stock is trapped in a downtrend, which has been clearly marked in the daily Nike price chart below. The technical indicators - RSI and MFI - fail to indicate any signs of reversal as of yesterday. Click to enlarge Source: TradingView If the year-long downward channel is breached on the downside, there is a strong probability that the correction extends down to $40, which acted as a strong resistance earlier. The same has been marked in the daily chart above. But, if the stock were to negate the selling pressure and head higher, it will have to cross the formidable resistance of $56, beyond which significant short covering can be observed. At this point, I also want to address Nike's short interest which is at a 5-year high. It must be understood well that even at the multi-year highs, the short interest is just 2.06 percent of the outstanding float, which is nothing to be concerned about. So, investors are advised to look past the scary headlines and find out the actual merit. Click to enlarge If the $56 resistance is taken out, then we will definitely see a retreat in the short positions but, if the channel is breached on the downside, then we may see fresh short positions building up as well. The support level of $48 is the key. Let us also take a look at the monthly Nike price chart which spans almost two decades. After the debacle of 2008-09, Nike began an uptrend which lasted until late-2012. Come 2013, the stock began another uptrend although this time on a higher slope (highlighted in dotted line). Just few months ago, the stock violated the higher slope uptrend and has been declining since. Check out below. Click to enlarge Source: TradingView My bear -case expectation is that the stock will now attempt to take support from the much stronger and more sustainable support, extrapolated from the 2009-2012 uptrend. Interestingly, the present value of this support comes close to $40. Another reason why $40 could mark a strong reversal point is because it marks the 50 percent Fibonacci retracement level of the entire rally from 2009-2015. The stock, after taking support from the 23.6 percent Fib retracement, decisively violated it. The next Fib support is the 38.2 percent retracement level of $45.79, but the market generally views the 50 percent retracement as a stronger reversal level. It must also be noted from the monthly chart above that the Money Flow has dropped to 33.9860, a level not seen in the last 20 years . This is a strong indication of the underlying bearishness, and forces me to wait for better levels before recommending a buy. If the stock does drop 20 percent from the current level, it would bring many fundamental metrics in-line with their 5-year averages or even lower. Please see the valuation data below pulled from Morningstar which suggests that several ratios such as Price/Sales, Price/Cash Flows, Price/Book, Price/Forward Earnings are trading at 10-15 percent premiums to their 5-year averages. Click to enlarge Source: Morningstar.com A 20 percent drop will also push the current earnings yield of 4.35 percent to a level not seen since 2008. All of this confirms the same thing: That levels closer to $40 would be attractive from both technical and fundamental perspectives . Conclusion Nike has been battling weakness since the beginning of this year, however, investors do not have to add to their long positions now. The stock is trapped in a downward channel, which if pierced on the downside, could open the gates to $40. It has been well established both fundamentally and technically that another 20 percent drop would make the stock a very juicy affair. It would also attract significant buying interest from those investors who have been sitting on the sidelines with idle cash. That would lay the foundation of a sustainable recovery in the stock price. Only above the resistance of $56 should investors expect to see more gains and renewed short covering. Note : I cover several stocks in different sectors as well as S&P 500, crude oil, gold and silver, U.S. dollar, etc. So, if you liked this update, and would like to read more of such informative articles, please consider hitting the "Follow" button above. Thank you for reading! Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. About this article: Expand Author payment: $35 + $0.01/page view. thread.section_title: Men's Journal Latest Health & Fitness News
thread.title: Are ‚ÄòStrobe Glasses‚Äô the Future of Injury Recovery?
thread.title_full: Are ‚ÄòStrobe Glasses‚Äô the Future of Injury Recovery?

posts.title: Are ‚ÄòStrobe Glasses‚Äô the Future of Injury Recovery?
posts.text:
By Melaina Juntti Washington Nationals left fielder Corey Brown wears a pair of Nike Sparq Strobe sports vision training glasses during a vision workout. Credit: Getty Images 
If you blow out your knee or have major joint surgery, your doctor will likely recommend or even require physical therapy. By doing repeated physical exercises, you relearn how to move that body part, which can certainly help you get back up to speed. However, a new study suggests PT skips a key component of recovery: retraining the brain. MORE: How to Injury-Proof Your Body 
Using MRI scans on patients recovering from ACL reconstructions, researchers at The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center discovered that their brains processed information from their injured leg differently than from their healthy leg ‚Äî and differently than how uninjured people process info. These guys relied much more heavily on visual cues when moving their reconstructed knee and didn‚Äôt move it as instinctively as they did their other knee. 
‚ÄúWhen we asked participants to move their leg in a simple bend, the MRIs showed they used a visual processing system, even though this was not a visual task,‚Äù says Jimmy Onate, lead researcher and director of Health and Rehabilitation Sciences at OSU. ‚ÄúThere was no reason to use their vision ‚Äî they were not asked to avoid obstacles or use their eyesight in any way. But because nerve endings get damaged with musculoskeletal injuries, we think people begin relying on vision more to use, control, and monitor their movements.‚Äù ALSO: What's Really Causing Your Running Injuries 
The problem with becoming overly dependent on your eyes is that you end up not retraining the joint to move naturally. Furthermore, you‚Äôre kidnapping your vision and devoting it to otherwise simple movements, when it would be better served watching out for fallen branches on your running trail or anticipating the next pass on the basketball court. 
‚ÄúThink about vision from a cost-of-resources standpoint,‚Äù Onate says. ‚ÄúWe only have a certain amount of it. If you‚Äôre walking down a wide, brightly lit hallway and don‚Äôt need to judge whether to go faster or slower or move right or left, then you can afford to use some of your vision for movement. But if you need to react to anything ‚Äî say, you‚Äôre crossing a busy road or you‚Äôre on the court and need to know where the ball is and where your teammates are ‚Äî then you don‚Äôt want to use up your vision on moving your knee.‚Äù 
Now that the researchers have discovered this disparity in information processing, they‚Äôve begun testing out a method to fix it. In hopes of training patients to not depend on vision after ACL reconstruction, they‚Äôre having them wear stroboscopic eyewear during some physical therapy sessions. Also dubbed ‚Äústrobe glasses,‚Äù these dark-hued specs are similar to sunglasses, making it much tougher to see in a bright therapy setting. But they also have shutters that open and close rapidly, creating a strobe light‚Äìlike effect that interferes, distorts, and forces the body to move instinctively rather than by sight. 
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre taking away some of their vision but not blinding them completely and then also adding the visual-disturbance element,‚Äù Onate says. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just rehab someone on a soccer field because their leg is not ready.‚Äù But by re-teaching movements in a safe environment with impaired vision, Onate feels they can better prepare patients for resuming real life and real activities. 
Stroboscopic eyewear isn‚Äôt entirely new in the world of sports. Since these glasses came onto the scene a few years back, pro athletes have used them to help hone their skills and quicken their reaction times. In 2013, Duke University researchers even tested them out on members of the NHL‚Äôs Carolina Hurricanes. After wearing the glasses during their 16-day preseason training camp, players performed 18 percent better on shooting and passing tests than their teammates who didn‚Äôt sport the specs. 
But bringing stroboscopic eyewear into the therapy setting is an entirely new concept, one that Onate thinks may have real merit. ‚ÄúUsing these glasses in physical therapy is not mainstream by any means, and we‚Äôre still looking at the pros and cons and for how long and when they should be used,‚Äù he says. But if Onate‚Äôs next round of experiments proves successful, strobe glasses could soon become an ingrained part of PT. 
Onate warns that people with seizures, migraines, or past concussions steer clear of strobe glasses because they may exacerbate symptoms. But for everyone else recovering from injury, he advocates trying them at home ‚Äî that is, if you want to spring the $400 for the glasses online . Just don‚Äôt use them right out of the gate. ‚ÄúWe do almost all activities with eyes open at first,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúNext you can move onto eyes closed. Then later, when you‚Äôre working on single-leg movements and other exercises, you can try the glasses.‚Äù

posts.title: Nike Introduce the Next Generation of Air Force 1s ‚Äì Sneaker Freaker
posts.text:
Previous Next 
UPDATE: Swooping in without warning this past November, the Nike SF Air Force 1 has quickly established itself as one of 2016s most coveted silhouettes ‚Äì and none more so than this white-on-white rendition. Originally thought to be a ComplexCon exclusive, it looks like the crispy clean colourway will be seeing a wider release through select Nike Sportswear stockists in Asia from December 1. 
No word on numbers yet, nor do we have any confirmation of these showing up in other regions. If you‚Äôre in Asia, march on down to your local retailer if you want to cop this military marvel. Previous Next 
After teasing the silhouette at the end of October, Nike have gone the whole hog on the announcement of the next generation of Air Force 1 s. Since 1982 the shoe has been changing and evolving with each new generation morphing into a force to be reckoned with. We‚Äôve seen the shoe take on new weaves, higher and lower profiles, fusions and zips ‚Äì and now we‚Äôre seeing it turn into this SF utilitarian adaption. 
The newest version in the lineage goes sky high with the collar and comes clad in fortified materials. With a full grain leather and ballistic nylon build, interchangeable straps and ‚ÄòEspionage Tongue Storage‚Äô, it definitely has some Batman -esque gadgetry sensibilities. But it also slots in seamlessly with the current fashion climate. A military inspired carry bag also comes with the SF AF1, which has the same detachable straps as the shoe. 
All colourways of the Nike SF Air Force 1 will be available on November 5 from the SNKRS page of Nike online , bar the white version which will be exclusive to ComplexCon. 
On foot images via

thread.title: What it's like to wear Nike's HyperAdapt self-lacing sneakers
thread.title_full: What it's like to wear Nike's HyperAdapt self-lacing sneakers

posts.author: Adario Strange
posts.title: What it's like to wear Nike's HyperAdapt self-lacing sneakers
posts.text:
Even the most tech-averse will admit that they'd like to step, even if just briefly, into a shoe from the future. That's what Nike is promising with its self-lacing sneakers that have leapt from Hollywood screens into reality.
Nike put the dream of self-lacing shoes into the minds of sci-fi and sneaker fans when Michael J. Fox donned a fictional pair in 1989's Back to the Future Part II . By 2015, the year the movie is set, Nike had seemingly perfected the technology in real life, first announcing the Nike Air Mags , replicas of the sneakers Fox wears in the movie, and later the HyperAdapt ‚Äî a self-lacing sneaker Nike intends to sell as an actual product.
SEE ALSO: Nike's self-lacing sneakers are coming soon, but they're going to cost you ... a lot
I got a chance to try out Nike's HyperAdapt shoes, finally getting a chance to find out how real-deal self-lacing sneakers actually feel. Are they just slick, logo-emblazoned technology you'll quickly regret spending your cash on, or is this the future of footwear?
Are they just slick, logo-emblazoned technology, or is this the future of footwear?
That's the question I wanted to answer when I visited Nike's little known Nike+ Clubhouse, not far from its new Niketown store location in Soho, New York City.
When I slipped on the size-14 HyperAdapts (the shoes are unisex, so a woman needing a size 8 would wear a HyperAdapt men's 6.5) with the much-talked-about battery and lacing mechanism embedded in its sole, I wasn‚Äôt expecting much in the way of comfort. Let's just say the shoes surpassed my expectations. The shoe not only looks better in person ‚Äî it feels about as comfortable as any Nike I've worn. In fact, in keeping with most of Nike's line of running shoes, the HyperAdapt is amazingly lightweight. You'd never know the shoe was even special without seeing its LED lighting arrays in the sole and heel.
Similarly, the wireless charging pucks that magnetically snap onto the bottom of the shoes are light enough that tossing them into your backpack or purse won't add significant weight to your travels.
Image: MASHABLE, LILI SAMS
But the real test was the lacing mechanism. With so many different foot shapes out there, could Nike have actually developed a lacing system that doesn't just squeeze your foot into the shoe, but actually supports your foot like traditional laces? I've only worn the shoes for an hour, but my early impression is: absolutely.
Yo this is crazy I'm officially part of the @Nike family! Trust me there's more to come but for now step into the future with me! üòú #TeamNike #HyperAdapt
A video posted by michaelbjordan (@michaelbjordan) on Nov 29, 2016 at 3:59pm PST
"There's a lace engine [in the shoe] and it has a motor and spool and there's a cable that winds up on that spool," says Tiffany Beers, a senior innovator at Nike who has worked on the shoe for about 10 years. "Leading up to that you have a couple lace cables they come up and wind through [the surface of the shoe] in a very specific pattern to give you just the right fit and adjustability."
Tiffany Beers, Senior Innovator at Nike
Image: MASHABLE, LILI SAMS
I tested this mechanism a number of ways, and although the lacing mechanism is incredibly strong and supportive during wear, it doesn't pinch your foot or errant fingers with enough force to result in injury.
"[The laces are] a braided piece of nylon," says Beers. "We call it the parachute. The whole goal of it is to give you a visual representation of the shoe's closing. They also help to distribute pressure."
Still, I couldn't help but wonder if knockoff sneaker makers will attempt to replicate the HyperAdapt, possibly putting less than safe, would-be self-lacing sneakers on the market.
Image: MASHABLE, LILI SAMS
"Eventually people will be able to reverse-engineer this and figure out how we did it," says Beers. "The thing about it is that it's such a particular system to get the fit right and to get the mechanism built right. They're going to have to have electronics backgrounds."
Very true. But it won't stop them from trying.
Image: mashable, Adario strange
The HyperAdapt offers another cool feature: automatic lacing. So even if you don't use the plus or minus buttons to adjust the fit, when you put the shoes on, once you start walking, sensors in the heel detect your motion and begin tightening the shoe to a comfortable level of snugness.
Another nice surprise: If you ever feel like the shoes are perhaps not as responsive or functioning as they should be, the HyperAdapts can reboot. Just hold down the plus and minus buttons for 13 seconds and watch as the normally blue-green LEDs on the its heel and sole display a rainbow of red, yellow and purple flashes. Cool.
Image: MASHABLE, LILI SAMS
Aside from the fit and the design, I also wondered if tagging the shoe "E.A.R.L." (which stands for Electro Adaptive Reactive Lacing) was Nike's way of previewing a future Siri- or Alexa-style voice command system that allows you to adjust the fit of your Nike shoes and clothing in the future?
"I can't share all of the secrets with you," Beers says. "A lot of these technologies are still in their infancy and we need to let them develop."
Nike will release the black version of the HyperAdapt on Dec. 1, and Beers says a silver version is coming for the Christmas season. Along with those versions, she also confirmed that a white version, with a gum rubber sole, with be distributed to "friends of the brand." NBA star Kyrie Irving showed off that version on Monday via Twitter.
Yessir! Thanks @Nike pic.twitter.com/bXL1zbWNOw
‚Äî Kyrie Irving (@KyrieIrving) November 28, 2016
So is Nike's HyperAdapt the best attempt at fashion-meets-tech we've seen to date?
Short answer: Yes.
But the real challenge for Nike will be price. At $720, these are pricey as both a piece of tech and a pair of sneakers. Sure, for footwear in general, they're comfortably below the wares of Manolo and Ferragamo, but as trendy tech accessories go, the HyperAdapt sneakers are out of range for most, surpassing even the Apple Watch . Let's not forget Snapchat's Spectacles are just $129.
But in Nike's case, the wearable tech outlook may be brighter. My prediction is that if Nike can, in coming years, soften the blow on your wallet by a few hundred dollars, it's likely we'll see HyperAdapt's self-lacing technology everywhere.
Welcome (back) to the future of wearable tech.
BONUS: Nike‚Äôs self-lacing sneakers are on their way, but they ain‚Äôt cheap

thread.title: Nike to move into 70,000 square-foot Fifth Ave. store
thread.title_full: Nike to move into 70,000 square-foot Fifth Ave. store | New York Post

posts.author: Lois Weiss
posts.title: Nike to move into 70,000 square-foot Fifth Ave. store
posts.text:
Nike is swooshing into a huge, 70,000 square-foot store at 650 Fifth Ave. on the southwest corner of West 52 Street ‚Äî across from Cartier and Olympic Tower.
The deal is valued at $700 million over its 15-year term and includes additional options, sources said.
The lease was approved and signed late Tuesday with SL Green Realty Corp. and Jeff Sutton, who control the retail base of the 36-story office building that is operated under a federal trustee.
Nike was represented by Joanne Podell of Cushman & Wakefield.
The new superstore will include the lower level along with the first six floors of the building.
To get to yes with Nike, Sutton and SL Green bought out the two remaining tenants and added the fourth to sixth floors to their original holdings through an additional lease that had to be approved by the building‚Äôs trustee and the federal government.
The Commercial Observer reported two current tenants, Godiva and Devon & Blake, were bought out of their leases in order to give the athletic sportswear giant a full, 100 feet of frontage along Fifth Avenue.
Nike has another large flagship a few blocks north at 6 E. 57 St. in a building controlled by President-elect Donald Trump that is adjacent to the rear of Trump Tower. The company previously picked up an option to remain there until 2022.
The retailer also just opened a newly built 55,000-square-foot store at 529 Broadway in a building partially owned by Sutton that paved the way for this deal.
FindTheCompany | Graphiq Developed when Iran was governed by the former Shah, 650 Fifth became subject to forfeiture to the US government under the original embargo.
To unlock the value and provide funds to maintain the building, Sutton and SL Green were granted a 49-year lease that runs through 2062. The deal for 33,000 square feet originally included the lower level and the first three floors. The group then bought out tenant Juicy Couture for $51 million.
Because it was slow to respond to availabilities in the past, Nike lost other prime spaces ‚Äî including at the former FAO Schwarz space at 767 Fifth Ave. where rival Under Armour recently leased.
None of the companies or brokers responded to requests for comment.

thread.title: US Sports Camps Releases Summer 2017 Dates for Nike Basketball Camps at Curry College
thread.title_full: US Sports Camps Releases Summer 2017 Dates for Nike Basketball Camps at Curry College

posts.author: Steve Pence
posts.title: US Sports Camps Releases Summer 2017 Dates for Nike Basketball Camps at Curry College
posts.text:
Located minutes from Boston, Massachusetts, Curry College has become a staple for Nike Basketball Camps , attracting campers from around the world for six weeks of basketball, competition, and fun. Former professional player and Camp Director, David Harrison, and the superior staff of MB Sports Camps are excited for another summer at Curry College. Overnight and day camps run from June 25th until August 4th with an action-packed daily schedule of drills, skill stations, and tournaments. Campers 9-18 years old and of all skill levels looking to gain a deeper knowledge of the game and grow on and off the court are invited to attend.
Unique to Curry College, campers will have the opportunity to partake in nightly off-campus activities. These activities are available for extended day and overnight campers during the week and on the weekends. Past activities have included MLS and MLB games, bowling, laser tag, 6 Flags, whale watching, and much more. Activities are not mandatory and there will be plenty of on-campus activities for campers to choose from, including but not limited to movies, board games, and swimming.
For more details or to register online, visit http://www.ussportscamps.com/basketball/nike/nike-basketball-camp-curry-college/ or call 1-800-NIKE-CAMP.
About US Sports Camps
US Sports Camps (USSC) , headquartered in San Rafael, California, is America‚Äôs largest sports camp network and the licensed operator of Nike Sports Camps. Over 80,000 kids attended a US Sports Camps program in 2016. The company has offered summer camps since 1975 with the same mission that defines it today: to shape a lifelong enjoyment of athletics through high quality sports education and skill enhancement.

thread.title: Amazon, Kohl‚Äôs, Home Depot, Nike and Dick‚Äôs Supply Chain Executives to Keynote at eft‚Äôs 2nd Annual D3: Dynamic Distribution Disruption ‚Äì Retail Summit in New York
thread.title_full: Amazon, Kohl‚Äôs, Home Depot, Nike and Dick‚Äôs Supply Chain Executives to Keynote at eft‚Äôs 2nd Annual D3: Dynamic Distribution Disruption ‚Äì Retail Summit in New York

posts.author: Fabia Palmer
posts.title: Amazon, Kohl‚Äôs, Home Depot, Nike and Dick‚Äôs Supply Chain Executives to Keynote at eft‚Äôs 2nd Annual D3: Dynamic Distribution Disruption ‚Äì Retail Summit in New York
posts.text:
The biggest so-called holiday shopping weekend of the year just ended. The result: some shops wrecked due to big crowds, websites crashed due to high traffic, while other millions of shoppers decided to #OptOutside ditching Black Friday altogether. Regardless, one thing is certain ‚Äì retail is going through a major disruption. This disruption is driven by consumer preferences, and can be solved through a robust supply chain. The movers and shakers of retail are gathering in May in New York for the D3 Retail Summit: https://goo.gl/3S2x4d . Leading physical and online merchants, including Amazon, Kohl‚Äôs, Home Depot, Aldo and Nike, will blaze a trail for the industry through an omnichannel future in which supply chain will increasingly represent retailers‚Äô USP. The Home Depot recently announced that they will be returning in May for the keynotes. ‚ÄúThe D3 Summit was an outstanding event. The opportunity to meet with high level executives in supply chain in an intimate setting, provided for great candor and conversation. Everyone walked away highly energized with a larger network of experts and friends to leverage in the future,‚Äù commented Scott Spata, Home Depot‚Äôs VP of Supply Chain about the summit this year, and will be representing the company at D3 in May.
Discussions will center around eight key themes: consumer-driven supply chain, demand forecasting, inventory strategy, warehouse optimization, supplier collaboration, logistics and last-mile delivery, network redesign and route optimization, and organizational alignment. Download the brochure for more details: https://goo.gl/3S2x4d
Priyanka Asera, Head of Retail at eft and D3‚Äôs principal architect, believes that the excitement around the event is a reflection of the retail industry having arrived at a crossroads. ‚ÄúDistribution and supply chain are no longer backroom functions, they are a core part of every retailer‚Äôs business and therefore require a more holistic, strategic approach,‚Äù Asera explains. ‚ÄúIt is also incredibly exciting that we have Amazon involved as part of the keynotes since Amazon is the biggest enabler of pushing retail out of its comfort zone. Alexis is fantastic ‚Äì and she is also the former VP of Operations at Target so she brings a wealth of all-round experience with her.‚Äù
Confirmed speakers include:
Alexis DePree, VP Global Customer Fulfilment, Amazon Ratnakar Lavu, CTO, Kohl‚Äôs Scott Spata, VP Supply Chain, The Home Depot Eileen Meade, VP Omnichannel Strategy, Dicks Sporting Goods Darrell Edwards, Chief Supply Chain Officer, La-Z-Boy Jeff Girard, SVP Logistics, DSW Don La France, SVP Supply Chain Technology, 1800flowers Jonathan Parks, VP Global Operations & Logistics, Rent-a-Center Bryan Eshelman, COO, Aldo Neil Beckerman, SVP Supply Chain and Finance, New York & Co. Pooja Agarwal, VP Operations, Birchbox Mike Griswold, VP Retail Research, Gartner
Chairing the summit is Hugh Williams, Managing Director at Hughenden Consulting, who will oversee two days of lively debate encompassing a broad cross-section of departments and companies. Williams said, "I believe it is critical for retailers to be conscious of the needs of the customer in everything they do. But that is only half the story. They also need to work closely with all their supply chain partners to ensure that they all move away from the traditional push system to truly being demand-led. Retailers must take responsibility for driving the supply chain and building true partnerships."
Sponsors of the D3 Summit include Mercury Gate, B-Stock Solutions, Convey, project44, Bringg, Macropoint, Transfix and AFS.
For detailed information on the agenda, 40+ speakers, venue and more, download the brochure: https://goo.gl/3S2x4d
If companies are interested in getting involved, they are encouraged to contact Priyanka Asera via the details below. To set up interviews with any of the speakers, please get in touch with the media and press contact below.

eft Supply Chain and Logistics Business Intelligence is the global leader in business intelligence and C-level networking for the transport, logistics and supply chain industry. We specialize in connecting senior industry executives with their industry peers, and with the crucial information they need to excel in their work. http://www.eft.com

thread.title: Nike Introduce the Next Generation of Air Force 1s
thread.title_full: Nike Introduce the Next Generation of Air Force 1s

posts.author: Rob Marfell
posts.title: Nike Introduce the Next Generation of Air Force 1s
posts.text:
Previous Next 
UPDATE: Swooping in without warning this past November, the Nike SF Air Force 1 has quickly established itself as one of 2016s most coveted silhouettes ‚Äì and none more so than this white-on-white rendition. Originally thought to be a ComplexCon exclusive, it looks like the crispy clean colourway will be seeing a wider release through select Nike Sportswear stockists in Asia from December 1. 
No word on numbers yet, nor do we have any confirmation of these showing up in other regions. If you‚Äôre in Asia, march on down to your local retailer if you want to cop this military marvel. Previous Next 
After teasing the silhouette at the end of October, Nike have gone the whole hog on the announcement of the next generation of Air Force 1 s. Since 1982 the shoe has been changing and evolving with each new generation morphing into a force to be reckoned with. We‚Äôve seen the shoe take on new weaves, higher and lower profiles, fusions and zips ‚Äì and now we‚Äôre seeing it turn into this SF utilitarian adaption. 
The newest version in the lineage goes sky high with the collar and comes clad in fortified materials. With a full grain leather and ballistic nylon build, interchangeable straps and ‚ÄòEspionage Tongue Storage‚Äô, it definitely has some Batman -esque gadgetry sensibilities. But it also slots in seamlessly with the current fashion climate. A military inspired carry bag also comes with the SF AF1, which has the same detachable straps as the shoe. 
All colourways of the Nike SF Air Force 1 will be available on November 5 from the SNKRS page of Nike online , bar the white version which will be exclusive to ComplexCon. 
On foot images via

thread.title: Nike rolls out sneakers with self-tying laces - MarketWatch
thread.title_full: Nike rolls out sneakers with self-tying laces - MarketWatch

posts.author: Sara Germano
posts.title: Nike rolls out sneakers with self-tying laces - MarketWatch
posts.text:
Nike Inc. this week begins selling a pricey sneaker with self-tying laces, a high-stakes test of the company's technology investments and efforts to sell more products directly to consumers.
Since its founding, Nike has predominantly been a wholesaler. But as shopping shifts online, Nike is moving to lessen its reliance on retailers. It wants to double its direct sales to consumers to $16 billion by 2020, particularly as rivals Adidas AG and Under Armour Inc. have become more competitive in recent years.
That is where the self-lacing $720 HyperAdapt sneakers play a role. The company is offering the shoes exclusively on its relaunched Nike+ app and at a new retail store in New York City, beginning on Thursday. The idea is to hook consumers into buying via its app or visiting Nike stores for limited-edition sneaker releases, which to date has been a near-weekly phenomenon at Foot Locker and other retailers.
The move could put the squeeze on an already consolidating sporting goods retail industry, analysts say. Nike currently is the single-largest vendor to big chains like Dick's Sporting Goods Inc., Foot Locker Inc. and Finish Line Inc., accounting for 20%, 72%, and 73% of merchandise purchased, respectively, according to regulatory filings.
"They have to be worried about it," said John Kernan, senior retail analyst for brokerage Cowen & Co. He pointed to recent efforts by Dick's to create some of its own products and provide more shelf space to Under Armour and Adidas. Dick's didn't respond to a request for comment.
Kasper Rorsted, the new chief executive of Adidas, said of the self-lacing shoes, "I don't know if that's a save-the-world product," but sales through mobile devices and apps will continue to grow within the industry.
Asked for his perspective on the HyperAdapt launch, Foot Locker CEO Dick Johnson said on a November earnings call that Nike has "very limited peers in the marketplace" and has the bandwidth to launch some of its product via its own retail channels.
The HyperAdapt release comes after a decade of changes within Nike to expand into technology and consumer services.
"There was a moment of realization, when Nike people looked around and saw everyone running around with an iPod, that was when we knocked on the door of Apple," said Roberto Tagliabue, who was a director of digital innovation at Nike from 2005 through 2009.
He oversaw the launch of the first Nike+ product, a sensor placed in running shoes that synced with early iPods. The idea was to keep customers communicating with Nike long after they left the store.
Beth Sasseen, a recruiter who worked at Nike from 2007 to 2009, said her focus was on finding tech-savvy talent who could help develop more personalized products and software to better engage with consumers. Nike "was trying to be ahead of the game," she said.
Nike's push into tech wasn't without its setbacks. The original Nike+ sensor evolved into a series of wristbands, including the FuelBand, first launched in 2012. But it was discontinued in 2014 when the company decided to scrap hardware development altogether and focus on software and apps.
Meanwhile, Under Armour purchased a suite of fitness-tracking apps between 2013 and 2015 to create a network of more than 190 million users to market more shirts and shoes. Another fitness app, Strava, is popular among Nike employees, who have recorded thousands of runs around their Beaverton, Ore.,campus, according to interviews with staffers and data from Strava's website.
Nike began upgrading training apps of its own, including Nike+ Run Club and Nike+ Training Club, which include coaching tips from star athletes like Serena Williams and Ashton Eaton. The company returned to the gadget market this fall with a swoosh-branded version of the Apple Watch.
Mr. Tagliabue, who has since started his own Silicon Valley design firm, said Nike operates differently than other tech firms. "They cannot bring to market products that are not perfect" and risk damaging the brand, he said. "At Nike, sometimes you can get frustrated because things go slow."
Nike's digital sport team has spent roughly $100 million on software products, including the new Nike + app, over the past four years, according to a person familiar with the matter. The department has also been hit by turnover, with some members departing for Under Armour, Alphabet Inc.'s Google and others, the person said.
Nike said it doesn't disclose spending figures. The company announced in February it was naming Adam Sussman as chief digital officer, shortly before the HyperAdapt shoes and new apps were unveiled. Development on self-lacing technology began over a decade ago, and today's HyperAdapts are intended to be the first version of what Nike calls "adaptive performance" products.
So far, some Nike aficionados are excited about the futuristic shoes, if not the price. Hunter Harpin of North Adams, Mass., said he buys a pair of custom Nikes every year but the HyperAdapts just aren't worth the extra cost.
"It takes me two seconds to tie my own shoes," he said, "so I think I'd have a $200 limit on self-lacing sneakers."
Write to Sara Germano at sara.germano@wsj.com
More from MarketWatch How Election 2016 Changed the Political Parties Oil prices keep a grip on rally after OPEC deal; Brent atop $52 a barrel Why is Hillary Clinton hiking so much?

thread.title: Nike's Flyknit training shoes made for the gym
thread.title_full: Nike's Flyknit training shoes made for the gym

posts.author: JEFF BANOWETZ Tribune News Service
posts.title: Nike's Flyknit training shoes made for the gym
posts.text:
December 1, 2016 12:00 AM Nike's Flyknit training shoes made for the gym By JEFF BANOWETZ Tribune News Service Order Reprint of this Story 
The Nike Free line has been at the forefront of the minimalist movement, which focuses on allowing the foot to keep its natural motion as much as possible, unencumbered by the structure of traditional shoes. The Nike Free Train Force Flyknit brings that thinking into the gym, with a breathable shoe that is great for exercise classes, lifting weights and cardio equipment. The design uses Nike's Flyknit technology to provide stability on the upper with very little material. 
The dual-density sole offers some cushioning for when you're jumping and provides a solid platform for when you're lifting. The sock-like fit is comfortable but still provides that locked-in feel you want when moving in multiple directions in a boot-camp style class or plyometrics. The design may cause some heads to turn (particularly if you go with the red or orange Flyknit), but the function delivers on the promise of a natural feel while still allowing you to safely perform any gym activity. 
$150, nike.com

posts.title: What it's like to wear Nike's HyperAdapt self-lacing sneakers
posts.text: What it's like to wear Nike's HyperAdapt self-lacing sneakers Published by Mashable on Thu, 01 Dec 2016 Even the most tech-averse will admit that they'd like to step, even if just briefly, into a shoe from the future. That's what Nike is promising with its self-lacing sneakers that have leapt from Hollywood screens into reality.Nike put the dream of self-lacing shoes into the minds of sci-fi and sneaker fans when Michael J. Fox donned a fictional pair in 1989's Back to the Future Part II. By 2015, the year the movie is set, Nike had seemingly perfected the technology in real life, first announcing the Nike Air Mags, replicas of the sneakers Fox wears in the movie, and later the HyperAdapta self-lacing sneaker Nike intends to sell as an actual product. Read more...More about Wearables, Fashion, Nike Hyperadapt, Hyperadapt, and Wearable Tech

thread.title: Blake Griffin And Jimmy Butler Are Ready To Do Battle With The Monstars
thread.title_full: Blake Griffin And Jimmy Butler Are Ready To Do Battle With The Monstars

posts.author: davelozo
posts.title: Blake Griffin And Jimmy Butler Are Ready To Do Battle With The Monstars
posts.text:
Screenshot via Nike 
I really feel bad for basketball people because their sport‚Äôs go-to movie is Space Jam , which sucks and was never good. So when it‚Äôs time to stick Blake Griffin and Jimmy Butler into a sneaker ad, someone in the marketing agency stands up and says, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs get some Space Jam references in there,‚Äù and no one disagrees.
So that‚Äôs what you get here ‚Äî thinly veiled shots from Griffin, Butler, and Bugs Bunny at the Golden State Warriors, who are fun and awesome, unlike Space Jam . The Monstars must be stopped because they are a ‚Äúsuper team‚Äù and Griffin and Butler have got this. One plays for the Clippers and one plays for the Bulls, so I don‚Äôt know how they can contractually unite to beat space aliens in street games, but I didn‚Äôt think up this ad.
Defy the Monstars.
@ BlakeGriffin32 and @ JimmyButler are ready to take the game back. https://t.co/cU8WXFiUzD ‚Äî 
Jordan (@Jumpman23) December 01, 2016 

It‚Äôs sort of crazy that Space Jam is basketball‚Äôs movie. How many better movies are there about basketball? 100? Love & Basketball , White Men Can‚Äôt Jump , Juwana Mann . The list is endless yet they want to make a Space Jam sequel for some strange reason. Why not an ad where Griffin and Butler dominate old-as-hell Woody Harrelson and Wesley Snipes in 2-on-2. Now I‚Äôd watch that for sure. 
( Jordan on Twitter )

The Monstars must be stopped because they are a ‚Äúsuper team‚Äù and Griffin and Butler have got this. One plays for the Clippers and one plays for the Bulls, so I don‚Äôt know how they can contractually unite to beat space aliens in street games, but I didn‚Äôt think up this ad.
Defy the Monstars.
@ BlakeGriffin32 and @ JimmyButler are ready to take the game back. https://t.co/cU8WXFiUzD ‚Äî
Jordan (@Jumpman23) December 01, 2016
It‚Äôs sort of crazy that Space Jam is basketball‚Äôs movie. How many better movies are there about basketball? 100? Love & Basketball , White Men Can‚Äôt Jump , Juwana Mann . The list is endless yet they want to make a Space Jam sequel for some strange reason. Why not an ad where Griffin and Butler dominate old-as-hell Woody Harrelson and Wesley Snipes in 2-on-2. Now I‚Äôd watch that for sure.
( Jordan on Twitter )

posts.title: Nike Gives Back Locally to Strengthen Communities and Get Kids Moving Through the Nike Community Impact Fund
posts.text:
December 01, 2016 at 12:00 PM EST Nike Gives Back Locally to Strengthen Communities and Get Kids Moving Through the Nike Community Impact Fund Nike Community Stores across the country are giving back $240,000 to their communities through recent grants by the Nike Community Impact Fund (NCIF). The NCIF is an innovative approach to grant-making that engages a committee of Nike employees and store athletes from across the U.S. to directly impact the local communities where they live and work by awarding grants to organizations that give youth early, positive experiences in sport and physical activity and strengthen communities. Community Stores in Detroit, Chicago, New Orleans, Ivy City in Washington, D.C., the Flatbush neighborhood in Brooklyn and East Los Angeles have awarded $240,000 in grants to 48 nonprofit organizations and schools, in partnership with CAF America, to support projects that build strong communities and give kids opportunities to experience the power of physical activity, sport and play. 
Nike Community Stores across the country are giving back $240,000 to their communities through recent grants by the Nike Community Impact Fund (NCIF). The NCIF is an innovative approach to grant-making that engages a committee of Nike employees and store athletes from across the U.S. to directly impact the local communities where they live and work by awarding grants to organizations that give youth early, positive experiences in sport and physical activity and strengthen communities. Community Stores in Detroit, Chicago, New Orleans, Ivy City in Washington, D.C., the Flatbush neighborhood in Brooklyn and East Los Angeles have awarded $240,000 in grants to 48 nonprofit organizations and schools, in partnership with CAF America, to support projects that build strong communities and give kids opportunities to experience the power of physical activity, sport and play. This Smart News Release features multimedia. View the full release here: http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20161201006001/en/ 
Nike Community Stores, including the Detroit Community Store, are giving back $240,000 to their communities through grants to youth organizations. (Photo: Business Wire) 
Since 2010, the Nike Community Impact Fund has awarded more than 375 nonprofit organizations with more than $3.75 million in grants. With this recent round of grants, the total impact for 2016 is $800,000, including grants in Oregon where NCIF began and the national expansion of the program. 
‚ÄúOur Community Store Ambassadors are passionate about getting involved in their communities,‚Äù said Caitlin Morris, Nike‚Äôs Senior Director of North America Community Impact. ‚ÄúBy connecting Nike‚Äôs Community Stores to local grant programs, we look forward to fostering even deeper connections to provide youth with early, positive experiences in sport and physical activity.‚Äù 
Grant Recipients Reflect the Health and Vitality of Local Communities 
At the Detroit Community Store, one recipient for the inaugural grant program is the Boys and Girls Club of Southeastern Michigan . The club is devoted to guiding and supporting children ages 6-18 in five core areas: the arts; character and leadership development; education and career development; health and life skills; and sports, fitness and recreation. With the grant, the organization will create a co-ed basketball league. 
Tim Carroll, Head Coach of the Detroit Community Store, oversaw the grant process in his community. ‚ÄúWe wanted to focus on organizations that are striving to make physical activity, play and sport a highly valued part of everyday life for our athletes in the Detroit area,‚Äù Carroll said. ‚ÄúThe Boys & Girls Club of Southeastern Michigan is doing just that through their co-ed basketball league.‚Äù 
He added, ‚ÄúOur Nike Store athletes already have a strong relationship with the Boys and Girls Club, spending a few days a week volunteering there. During the afterschool program they lead young athletes in games and activities. We‚Äôre excited to deepen our connection with them through this new grant.‚Äù 
‚ÄúWe are very grateful to our local Detroit Community Store, The Nike Community Impact Fund and CAF America for their support of our co-ed basketball league,‚Äù said Patrice Dicken, Club Director, Boys & Girls Club of Southeastern Michigan-Lloyd H. Diehl Club. ‚ÄúAt the Boys & Girls Club, we want our kids to succeed. Through the co-ed basketball team, we‚Äôll be able to provide even more opportunities for our youth to participate in a structured environment that will help them develop skills, increase fitness, learn strategy and practice good sportsmanship.‚Äù 
At the South Chicago Community Store, Caitlyn Hickey, Community Store Ambassador, emphasized the need to hire positive role models who want to be part of the local community. ‚ÄúAt the Chicago Community Store, we like to be a positive role model in kids‚Äô lives. Having Nike involved at their school is really impactful to these kids.‚Äù 
Prior to the grant process, the Chicago Community Store was already involved with the Gary Comer Youth Center, where Community Store Ambassadors‚Äîstore employees that have received training in providing early, positive experiences in sport and physical activity--have been helping kids who may be struggling in physical education classes, by working with them to move to the next level. They also talk to kids about career development, how to develop a resume and do interviews, and what life is like after high school. When the grant opportunity came up, Caitlin Hickey personally went out and helped school administrators through the step-by-step grant process. ‚ÄúIt was really rewarding to be involved in that portion of the grant process, helping them apply and eventually get chosen as a grant recipient,‚Äù said Hickey. 
International Expansion of NCIF 
Nike is proud to be expanding the Nike Community Impact Fund to Europe. Nike employees in Nike‚Äôs European Headquarters in Hilversum, Netherlands, and European Logistics Center in Laakdal, Belgium, will help direct more than $350,000 (USD) of Nike‚Äôs community investments in Europe. 
The first round of grants for these cities will be announced in 2017. 
Nike Community Impact Fund Awardees 
The following 48 organizations received grants from six U.S. Nike Community Stores, through the Nike Community Impact Fund at CAF America: Organization

thread.title: How Much Would You Pay To Never Tie Your Shoes Again?
thread.title_full: How Much Would You Pay To Never Tie Your Shoes Again? - TheStreet

posts.author: Brian Sozzi
posts.title: How Much Would You Pay To Never Tie Your Shoes Again?
posts.text: It's go time for one of Nike's ( NKE ) most innovative sneakers ever and time to say goodbye to tripping over your shoelaces. Nike first showed off its Hyperadapt sneakers in March. The sneakers feature what Nike calls "adaptive lacing" technology, which can automatically tweak the snugness of the shoe. There are two buttons on the side to tighten and loosen the laces. They obviously have to be charged, which is done via a wireless charging puck. A blue light on the sole of the shoe indicates a full charge, a yellow light warns a user the battery is dying and red is basically panic mode for sneakerheads. Slowing sales growth for Nike has been fueled by sluggish demand for its basketball sneakers in the face of greater competition from the Under Armour ( UA ) Stephen Curry basketball brand and new fashion offerings from Adidas ( ADDYY )

thread.title: Adidas just opened a new kind of store ‚Äî and Nike should be terrified
thread.title_full: Adidas just opened a new kind of store ‚Äî and Nike should be terrified

posts.author: Dennis Green (dgreen@businessinsider.com)
posts.title: Adidas just opened a new kind of store ‚Äî and Nike should be terrified
posts.text:
Adidas 
Adidas has opened a brand-new sprawling home for its offerings in New York City, just a few blocks from Times Square on 5th Ave.
The global flagship is four floors, including a lower level, and measures 45,000 square feet. That makes it the German sportswear giant's largest store in the world, and signifies the brand's increased focus on the US market in the midst of its American turnaround.
Adidas is also focusing on New York as part of its "key city" attack plan.
"We wanted to focus on elevating the brand in key cities, and New York City is a great place to start because it's a sport and fashion intersection," Claire Midwood, Senior VP of Concepts to Consumer, told The Street. 
The store features a design the company calls its "stadium retail concept" that takes inspiration from U.S. high school sports stadiums. To that end, the entrance to the store mimics the tunnels athletes typically walk through to get to the field, and between the first and second level, high school-style bleachers are set up overlooking 5th Ave and shoppers can watch either the street scene below or live games on the TVs.
Other features in the store include a stall selling juices and snacks, a personal fitness consultation area, and a customization area for both shoes and clothing. The store has "locker rooms" to try on product, and areas called "The Turf" and "The Track" to test out product before purchase.
Adidas 
All of Adidas most famous product is accounted for and has its own place in the store, including Originals like the Stan Smith and Superstar and new hot performance products like the Ultra-Boost, as well as new collaborations like Stella McCartney for Adidas and a limited partnership with Canadian-based sportswear manufacturer Reigning Champ.
Lines were long on December 1 , with customers looking to get first dips on some unique styles offered for the grand opening.
In November, chief rival Nike also opened a huge store in New York's Soho district , with a focus on technology and trial before purchase. The sportswear giants, it seems, have chosen NYC as the place to wage war.
Adidas

thread.title: Tiger to wear new Nike TW ‚Äô17 golf shoes at Hero World Challenge
thread.title_full: Tiger to wear new Nike TW ‚Äô17 golf shoes at Hero World Challenge

posts.author: Zak Kozuchowski
posts.title: Tiger to wear new Nike TW ‚Äô17 golf shoes at Hero World Challenge
posts.text:
Tiger to wear new Nike TW ‚Äô17 golf shoes at Hero World... Tiger to wear new Nike TW ‚Äô17 golf shoes at Hero World Challenge E-mail 
Tiger Woods will be wearing Nike‚Äôs new TW ‚Äô17 golf shoe this week at the Hero World Challenge, which is designed to accomodate the golfer‚Äôs revamped golf swing. 
According to Nike, Woods has been working on the design of the shoe with Tobie Hatfield, Nike‚Äôs Senior Director of Athlete Innovation, since July 2015. The inspiration for its design was Woods‚Äô new swing, in which Woods has shifted his dominance from his left leg to his right leg. Woods and Hatfield with the TW ‚Äô17. 
‚ÄúThis shoe is an absolutely integral part of my return to the sport I love and have missed so much,‚Äù Woods says. ‚ÄúNike really got in the zone with me. I knew Tobie and I were on to something special back when I tried on the first prototype. I feel supreme support from this shoe which leads to the utmost confidence when I step onto the course.‚Äù 
The most intriguing part of the shoe‚Äôs design is what Nike calls its ‚Äúduo‚Äôs strapping system concept,‚Äù which was added to keep Woods ‚Äúsecure and locked down in his shoe.‚Äù According to Nike, the TW ‚Äô17 is the only golf shoe Woods has worn since undergoing two back surgeries in the fall of 2015. 
The TW ‚Äô17 will be available in Spring 2017. Your Reaction?

thread.title: Nike Transformed the Benassi Slide Into a Slip-On Sneaker
thread.title_full: Nike Transformed the Benassi Slide Into a Slip-On Sneaker

posts.author: Hypebeast (info@hypebeast.com)
posts.title: Nike Transformed the Benassi Slide Into a Slip-On Sneaker
posts.text:
Nike's Benassi Slide isn't new to makeovers. Back in February, the kicks got a major leather-clad overhaul thanks to NikeLab and now the design is being transformed yet again -- this time into a comfy slip-on sneaker. Aptly dubbed the Benassi SLP, the design retains the sole unit of the aforementioned NikeLab drop and even comes with the slide's usual midfoot strap, in this case including it as an overlaying panel across the shoe's predominately suede upper. Joining the suede construction is mesh bootie that sees its materials extended to the silhouette's heel.
Debuting in a Black/Dark Mushroom/White colorway, the Benassi SLP is available now from atmos and should hit additional Nike Sportswear spots soon.
Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast.com

thread.title: Nike Wants High-Tech Shoes to be Mainstream (NKE)
thread.title_full: Nike Wants High-Tech Shoes to be Mainstream (NKE)

posts.author: Dan Moskowitz
posts.title: Nike Wants High-Tech Shoes to be Mainstream (NKE)
posts.text:
The Future of Nike‚Äôs HyperAdapt (NKE) By Dan Moskowitz | December 1, 2016 ‚Äî 11:44 AM EST 
NIKE, Inc.‚Äôs ( NKE ) HyperAdapt 1.0 goes on sale today. They won‚Äôt be easy to find, and they‚Äôre expensive, but that‚Äôs intended. In order to purchase the HyperAdapt 1.0, you will need to lay down $720. You will also need to have made a reservation at one of the two New York City Nike stores where the HyperAdapt 1.0 is being sold. The only other option is the Nike+ app. 
Nike doesn‚Äôt want its first version of self-lacing shoes to be easy to find and affordable. If that were the case, it wouldn‚Äôt drive excitement and demand. When supply is low, demand is high . By driving excitement now, Nike is setting up for the long haul. If the next version of the HyperAdapt offers improved technology at a cheaper price, then demand will absolutely increase. Based on what Nike is saying, the technology will improve. Currently, you must use buttons on the side of the shoes to tighten and loosen, but Nike wants that to become an automatic feature in the future, essentially where the shose detect that athlete‚Äôs motion and adjust accordingly. (See also, Why Adidas Has Been Beating Nike and Under Armour ) 
According to TechCrunch, Nike senior innovator and engineer Tiffany Beers, said, ‚ÄúThis could absolutely be a mainstream product. It doesn‚Äôt feel gimmicky after using it. Athletes move and change. And their environment is constantly moving and changing. So optimal fit is important. Why isn‚Äôt our shoe changing more with our foot? That speaks to the potential future of where this is going.‚Äù 
Beers added, ‚ÄúThis is a concept car. We‚Äôve tested it in training, running and basketball ‚Äî mostly in running to get the durability right.‚Äù 
If you want to further understand where Nike is going with this, the following statement is directly from the Nike website back in March: ‚Äúto embed the technical components into such a small space that the design moves with the body and absorbs the same force the athlete is facing.‚Äù 
For Nike, the HyperAdapt 1.0 represents the beginning of a long runway. If it works, then Nike will help seal its footwear domination. 
NKE has depreciated 23.66% over the past 12 months and currently offers a dividend yield of 1.42%.

thread.section_title: Kith and Ronnie Fieg Are Bringing Back One of Nike‚Äôs Most Sought-After Sneakers ‚Äì Footwear News
thread.title: Kith and Ronnie Fieg Are Bringing Back One of Nike‚Äôs Most Sought-After Sneakers
thread.title_full: Kith and Ronnie Fieg Are Bringing Back One of Nike‚Äôs Most Sought-After Sneakers

posts.author: Riley Jones
posts.title: Kith and Ronnie Fieg Are Bringing Back One of Nike‚Äôs Most Sought-After Sneakers
posts.text:
Kith, recipient of the 2016 Footwear News Achievement Awards Retailer of the Year , is teaming up with Nike for a limited-edition sneaker release that will have many feeling nostalgic.
To celebrate the opening of Kith‚Äôs Miami location, Fieg has partnered with Nike to release what he calls his ‚Äúfavorite shoe of all-time,‚Äù the Nike Air Force 1 Low ‚ÄúLinen.‚Äù The tan, pink, and white sneakers originally released as a Japan exclusive in 2001 as part of Nike‚Äôs fan-favorite ‚ÄúConcept Japan‚Äù range and have remained tucked away in the brand‚Äôs vaults ever since. Related Watch Cuba Gooding Jr., Spike Lee, Ansel Elgort and Michael Kors Go Off Script 
Select friends and family pairs of the Nike Air Force 1 Low ‚ÄúLinen‚Äù will feature custom packaging by artist Futura. Kith/Tyler Mansour In order to capture the original appeal, Kith and Nike have pulled out all the stops to re-create a one-to-one retro that mimics everything from the grade of premium leather to the narrow shape seen on the ‚ÄúLinen‚Äù Air Force 1 Low 15 years ago.
Meanwhile, the sneaker‚Äôs launch will also call back to its regional availability in 2001 with a release exclusively at Kith‚Äôs new Miami location at 1931 Collins Ave. Beginning on the store‚Äôs grand opening on Dec. 2, raffle opportunities will be presented on four different days over the course of the following two weeks.
‚ÄúThe timing was amazing, and I am beyond excited to be the one to help reintroduce my favorite shoe ever to the world. 2016 has been an incredible year, and I‚Äôve been able to live out so many of my personal dreams,‚Äù Fieg wrote on Instagram.
According to a press release from Kith, this will be the only opportunity to obtain the ‚ÄúLinen‚Äù Nike Air Force 1 Low, and the shoes will have a wider release in the future.
If you know me, you know my favorite shoe of all time is the AF1 Linen. Over a year ago I spoke with Nike about officially bringing back this grail. This shoe represents a different time for sneakers, a time before the game became commercialized. Back then it was about the hunt, and you either had to physically travel somewhere to get the pair you wanted, or you had to know someone who knew someone else that had them. I told the Swoosh that if these were to be brought back, they had to be done in a way that would honor its original release. Not only did the quality have to be perfect, but so did the way they are brought to market. Being a Japan exclusive in 2001, we agreed that they had to remain a shoe that wasn't sold online and was solely available in 1 place. Around this time I had begun work on another dream of mine ‚Äì opening a Kith Miami flagship. The timing was amazing, and I am beyond excited to be the one to help reintroduce my favorite shoe ever to the world. 2016 has been an incredible year, and I've been able to live out so many of my personal dreams. Here goes another one. A Kith Miami global exclusive. Stay tuned to @kith for more info. 
A photo posted by Ronnie Fieg (@ronniefieg) on Nov 30, 2016 at 6:04pm PST 
 
The Nike Air Force 1 Low ‚ÄúLinen‚Äù is a one-to-one reproduction of the original 2001 release. Kith/Tyler Mansour Ronnie Fieg calls the Nike Air Force 1 Low ‚ÄúLinen‚Äù his ‚Äúfavorite shoe of all time.‚Äù Kith/Tyler Mansour The Nike Air Force 1 Low ‚ÄúLinen‚Äù originally released as a Japan-exclusive in 2001. Kith/Tyler Mansour According to a press release from Kith, the Nike Air Force 1 Low ‚ÄúLinen‚Äù retro features a narrowed shape and premium leather. Kith/Tyler Mansour Kith and Nike are teaming up to bring back the ‚ÄúLinen‚Äù Air Force 1 Low. Kith/Tyler Mansour

Posted By: Kenny Honaker Posted date: December 01, 2016 In: NBA 
Over the years, Cleveland Cavaliers forward LeBron James has proven to be one of the most giving athletes of all time. Whether it be scholarships to kids in Akron or uniforms to area high school athletic programs, James has worked tirelessly to make a positive impact in Cleveland‚Äôs local communities. 
James‚Äô charitable hand reaches much further than Northeast Ohio, though, as two high school teams recently learned. 
RELATED: Kyrie Irving reacts to Tyronn Lue pulling starters from game 
On Monday, the boys basketball team of the four-time defending state champion West Linn High School Lions in Oregon received a surprise gift during practice drills. Boxes of brand new LeBron Soldier 10s were given to the student athletes; enclosed was an inspirational message from Nike and James. 
‚ÄúLions, 
Not two, not three, not four. Time to get number five, boys! 
You got some big shoes to fill this season. The target on your back has never been bigger. 
But if no one wants it more than you, no one can take your crown. 
Stay hungry, I‚Äôll be watching.‚Äù

thread.title: Nike Self-Lacing Shoes Prove The Future Is In Automation
thread.title_full: Nike Self-Lacing Shoes Prove The Future Is In Automation

posts.author: Conner Dial
posts.title: Nike Self-Lacing Shoes Prove The Future Is In Automation
posts.text:
Conner Dial 1 december 2016 
The Nike HyperAdapt 1:1 self-tying sneakers are nothing to scoff at. With an automated lace mechanism that allows wearers to adjust lace tightness on the fly and in the moment, Nike truly proves that automated tech isn‚Äôt a gimmick. Unlike the Nike Mag shoes that inspired it, Nike says that these sneakers are a performance shoe, not a collector‚Äôs item. 
Though the shoe is the result of over three years of research, it doesn‚Äôt feel too far out there. The shoe easily slips onto your foot and the adaptive lacing mechanism is triggered by standing on your heel. Two buttons on the side also make it easy to manually adjust tightness. The teal-colored block on the outsole warns you when the shoe is running low on battery, however, Nike ensures it can last two weeks on a single charge (and even more when you aren‚Äôt using the flash functionality). 
Coming in a beautiful, massive box, fit for its innovative tech, the Nike HyperAdapt 1:1 package comes with a usb charging kit, a customer service hotline number for Nike HyperAdapt users and a hefty $720 price tag. 
Nike Senior Innovator Tiffany Beers states that athletes were initially the core consumer as explosive, lateral movements require tighter laces, but often this can restrict movement and blood flow. The adaptive lace system allows athletes to easily change their shoe tightness. 
Bearing that in mind, the shoe was designed for general, cross-sport use, from low-impact cardio to explosive, drill-based work. While the shoes aren‚Äôt heavy, they aren‚Äôt as agile as sprint shoes. Nevertheless, if Nike‚Äôs adaptive lace system proves successful, there‚Äôs no doubt we will be seeing these in sport-specific iterations. 
Ultimately, the adaptive lace system has benefits for anyone with dexterity issues or mobile disabilities. Nike, who has a history of working with non profit organizations like the Parkinson‚Äôs Foundation, would like to develop the E.A.R.L (Electro Adaptive Reactive Lacing) system for universal use. For now, though, according to Beers, the HyperAdapt 1:1 is simply a ‚Äútest car.‚Äù

posts.text:
By: SL Green Realty Corp. via Business Wire News Releases December 01, 2016 at 16:15 PM EST SL Green and Jeff Sutton Sign 69,000 Square-Foot Lease with Nike for New Retail Store at 650 Fifth Avenue SL Green Realty Corp (NYSE: SLG), New York City‚Äôs largest commercial landlord, along with its partner Jeff Sutton, today announced that NIKE, Inc., the world‚Äôs leading designer, marketer and distributor of authentic athletic footwear, apparel, equipment and accessories for a wide variety of sports and fitness activities, signed a 15-year lease covering seven floors and 69,214 square feet at 650 Fifth Avenue. The lease comprises the building‚Äôs entire retail component. 
SL Green Realty Corp ( NYSE: SLG ), New York City‚Äôs largest commercial landlord, along with its partner Jeff Sutton, today announced that NIKE, Inc., the world‚Äôs leading designer, marketer and distributor of authentic athletic footwear, apparel, equipment and accessories for a wide variety of sports and fitness activities, signed a 15-year lease covering seven floors and 69,214 square feet at 650 Fifth Avenue. The lease comprises the building‚Äôs entire retail component. 
‚ÄúIt is a true honor to enter into this long-term partnership with such a respected global sports retail leader as Nike,‚Äù said Brett Herschenfeld, Managing Director. 
‚ÄúWe are excited about this partnership and look forward to continuing to bring consumers the very best of Nike in another new, unique brand experience store,‚Äù said Jeff Nichols, Vice President of Nike‚Äôs Direct to Consumer business in North America. 
Situated at West 52nd Street, 650 Fifth Avenue is a 36-story office building in the heart of the Plaza District. 
About SL Green Realty Corp. 
SL Green Realty Corp., an S&P 500 company and New York City's largest office landlord, is a fully integrated real estate investment trust, or REIT, that is focused primarily on acquiring, managing and maximizing value of Manhattan commercial properties. As of September 30, 2016, the Company held interests in 125 Manhattan buildings totaling 46.6 million square feet. This included ownership interests in 28.1 million square feet of commercial buildings and debt and preferred equity investments secured by 18.6 million square feet of buildings. In addition, the Company held ownership interests in 30 suburban buildings totaling 4.8 million square feet in Brooklyn, Long Island, Westchester County, Connecticut and New Jersey. 
To be added to the Company's distribution list or to obtain the latest news releases and other Company information, please visit our website at www.slgreen.com or contact Investor Relations at (212) 594-2700. 
About NIKE, Inc. 
NIKE, Inc., based near Beaverton, Ore., is the world‚Äôs leading designer, marketer and distributor of authentic athletic footwear, apparel, equipment and accessories for a wide variety of sports and fitness activities. Wholly owned NIKE, Inc. subsidiaries include Converse, Inc., which designs, markets and distributes athletic lifestyle footwear, apparel and accessories; and Hurley International LLC, which designs, markets and distributes surf and youth lifestyle footwear, apparel accessories. For more information, Nike‚Äôs earnings releases and other financial information are available at http://investors.nike.com . Individuals can also visit http://news.nike.com and follow @Nike.

The last time we covered any kind of information regarding the Nike LeBron 14 was a couple months ago when we let you know that the 14th Nike LeBron signature shoe would be making its debut sometime during the month of January (2017). The Nike LeBron 14 will release in January It is being reported that it will retail at $175 That‚Äôs about it. We had initially thought that this was the Nike LeBron 14 , but this latest info coming out of ESPN proves that that is not the case.
Dave McMenamin from ESPN recently reported that LeBron James was warming up in an all-black pair of LeBron 14‚Äôs during a shootaround in Cleveland this morning. They don‚Äôt look like the images that leaked in August at all. James let ESPN.com inspect them, as long as we promised not to take a photo, and they are very sharp. One clue to what to expect when they drop in January: strap. ‚Äù

thread.title: Nike's Self-Lacing HyperAdapt 1.0 Is Cool AF
thread.title_full: Nike's Self-Lacing HyperAdapt 1.0 Is Cool AF

posts.title: Nike's Self-Lacing HyperAdapt 1.0 Is Cool AF
posts.text:
Nike's Self Lacing HyperAdapt 1.0 Is Cool AF! You've GOT To See This Adaptive Lacing Hi-Tech Shoe In Action. Print Share   
Why is this important? 
Sneakerheads around the world have been breathlessly waiting for the self-lacing HyperAdapt 1.0 from Nike. 
Long Story Short 
Following the hype of the self-lacing "Back To The Future" Air Mags, Nike has finally released another silhouette powered by adaptive lacing. This pair retails at a cool $720 (Rs 50,000 approx.), and released today in the US and will be available only across two Nike stores in New York as of now. 
Long Story 
The self-lacing mechanism is similar to the Air Mags (remember Marty McFly‚Äôs self-lacing sneakers from Back to the Future Part II ?). The auto-buckling system resembles the way roller blades tighten. This is the first self-lacing shoe that will be directly available to the public. 
While these kicks are a definite dream for any professional athlete (you really don't want to be tying shoe laces midfield, halting a splendid match), copping a pair for yourself is sure to place you right up on the ladder of hypebeasts. 
The Hyperadapt 1.0 has a lightweight silhouette with a black and white lagoon colourway, which is going to be followed by metallic silver, black, and white colour ways soon. 
Tiffany Beers, Senior Innovator at Nike Inc, explains, "When you step in, your heel hits a sensor and the system automatically tightens. Then there are two buttons on the side to tighten and loosen. You can adjust it until it is perfect." Can lacing up be more fly? We think not. 
Since this is going to be battery operated, it made sense for the brand to include LED lights into the sole (talk about going hi-tech!) that showcase the battery life. Every full charge claims to make the battery last for a minimum of 2 weeks. DOPE. 
We're keeping our fingers crossed hoping for a India release soon.

thread.title: Nike Rolls Out High Tech Sneakers to Boost Direct Sales
thread.title_full: Nike Rolls Out High Tech Sneakers to Boost Direct Sales

posts.author: morningstar.com
posts.title: Nike Rolls Out High Tech Sneakers to Boost Direct Sales
posts.text:
By Sara Germano
Nike Inc. this week begins selling a pricey sneaker with self-tying laces, a high-stakes test of the company's technology investments and efforts to sell more products directly to consumers.
Since its founding, Nike has predominantly been a wholesaler. But as shopping shifts online, Nike is moving to lessen its reliance on retailers. It wants to double its direct sales to consumers to $16 billion by 2020, particularly as rivals Adidas AG and Under Armour Inc. have become more competitive in recent years.
That is where the self-lacing $720 HyperAdapt sneakers play a role. The company is offering the shoes exclusively on its relaunched Nike+ app and at a new retail store in New York City, beginning on Thursday. The idea is to hook consumers into buying via its app or visiting Nike stores for limited-edition sneaker releases, which to date has been a near-weekly phenomenon at Foot Locker and other retailers.
The move could put the squeeze on an already consolidating sporting goods retail industry, analysts say. Nike currently is the single-largest vendor to big chains like Dick's Sporting Goods Inc., Foot Locker Inc. and Finish Line Inc., accounting for 20%, 72%, and 73% of merchandise purchased, respectively, according to regulatory filings.
"They have to be worried about it," said John Kernan, senior retail analyst for brokerage Cowen & Co. He pointed to recent efforts by Dick's to create some of its own products and provide more shelf space to Under Armour and Adidas. Dick's didn't respond to a request for comment.
Kasper Rorsted, the new chief executive of Adidas, said of the self-lacing shoes, "I don't know if that's a save-the-world product," but sales through mobile devices and apps will continue to grow within the industry.
Asked for his perspective on the HyperAdapt launch, Foot Locker CEO Dick Johnson said on a November earnings call that Nike has "very limited peers in the marketplace" and has the bandwidth to launch some of its product via its own retail channels.
The HyperAdapt release comes after a decade of changes within Nike to expand into technology and consumer services.
"There was a moment of realization, when Nike people looked around and saw everyone running around with an iPod, that was when we knocked on the door of Apple," said Roberto Tagliabue, who was a director of digital innovation at Nike from 2005 through 2009.
He oversaw the launch of the first Nike+ product, a sensor placed in running shoes that synced with early iPods. The idea was to keep customers communicating with Nike long after they left the store.
Beth Sasseen, a recruiter who worked at Nike from 2007 to 2009, said her focus was on finding tech-savvy talent who could help develop more personalized products and software to better engage with consumers. Nike "was trying to be ahead of the game," she said.
Nike's push into tech wasn't without its setbacks. The original Nike+ sensor evolved into a series of wristbands, including the FuelBand, first launched in 2012. But it was discontinued in 2014 when the company decided to scrap hardware development altogether and focus on software and apps.
Meanwhile, Under Armour purchased a suite of fitness-tracking apps between 2013 and 2015 to create a network of more than 190 million users to market more shirts and shoes. Another fitness app, Strava, is popular among Nike employees, who have recorded thousands of runs around their Beaverton, Ore.,campus, according to interviews with staffers and data from Strava's website.
Nike began upgrading training apps of its own, including Nike+ Run Club and Nike+ Training Club, which include coaching tips from star athletes like Serena Williams and Ashton Eaton. The company returned to the gadget market this fall with a swoosh-branded version of the Apple Watch.
Mr. Tagliabue, who has since started his own Silicon Valley design firm, said Nike operates differently than other tech firms. "They cannot bring to market products that are not perfect" and risk damaging the brand, he said. "At Nike, sometimes you can get frustrated because things go slow."
Nike's digital sport team has spent roughly $100 million on software products, including the new Nike + app, over the past four years, according to a person familiar with the matter. The department has also been hit by turnover, with some members departing for Under Armour, Alphabet Inc.'s Google and others, the person said.
Nike said it doesn't disclose spending figures. The company announced in February it was naming Adam Sussman as chief digital officer, shortly before the HyperAdapt shoes and new apps were unveiled. Development on self-lacing technology began over a decade ago, and today's HyperAdapts are intended to be the first version of what Nike calls "adaptive performance" products.
So far, some Nike aficionados are excited about the futuristic shoes, if not the price. Hunter Harpin of North Adams, Mass., said he buys a pair of custom Nikes every year but the HyperAdapts just aren't worth the extra cost.
"It takes me two seconds to tie my own shoes," he said, "so I think I'd have a $200 limit on self-lacing sneakers."
Write to Sara Germano at sara.germano@wsj.com

thread.title: Nike's Flyknit Racers Are the Latest Sneakers to Jump On the Blackout
thread.title_full: Nike's Flyknit Racers Are the Latest Sneakers to Jump On the Blackout

posts.title: Nike's Flyknit Racers Are the Latest Sneakers to Jump On the Blackout
posts.text:
Twitter As stealthy as footwear gets in 2016. 
Nike's Flyknit Racers were an undisputed a game-changer in the sneaker industry when they were released in 2012. Not only were they incredibly lightweight and almost sci-fi in their futuristic appeal, but they instantly became go-to footwear for stylish men‚Äînot just those hitting the track. There was a deluge of Nike Flyknits in street style galleries and it didn't take long for the silhouette to reach near-iconic status. These days, Nike Flyknits are as commonplace as any other sneakers. And while the always-innovating Nike has worked tirelessly to improve upon the style, it's the original model that, in our humble opinion, still looks the best. And yesterday, the brand made things even better when they released the original Flyknit Racer in an undeniably cool all-black colorway. 
What made Nike Flyknits spark with the masses‚Äîits almost painful-to-look-at "volt" colorway that was marketing gold‚Äîhas now been completely inverted in this stealthy iteration. The "triple black" craze has taken over not just Nike, but brands like Adidas (which just released its all-black Ultra Boost today) and Under Armour (which dropped its all-black Curry 3 on Black Friday). What is about all-black sneakers that make them so covetable? Maybe it's that they look badass. Maybe it's that they make planning the rest of your outfit easy and look awesome with a gray suit. (And in some cases even work with a dressed-down tuxedo.) Or maybe it's they get less dirty than their all-white counterparts.
